Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2013 02:58AM Janet456 wrote: The waiting is horrible and sorry you have to be here. Same thing happened to me - my lump was large and rock solid.  After a few biopsies the surgeon said it had to come out as he didn't like the look of it and was not satisfied with the benign results.  They had alot of trouble inserting the wire guided placement prior to the lumpectomy as it was so hard. It was actually benign, although in the final pathology they did find a seperate small area of DCIS.  Mine was a tubular adenoma. Fingers crossed you get a benign result xxx

Posts.Title: very very afraid...inverted nipple and mass :( cancersein Janet456

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2012 08:57AM Janet456 wrote: I can only think that the radiologist saying that she had news you wouldn't like was due to the fact that you were going to have a biopsy done.  A biopsy will automatically be given against a birad 4 but they are still looking to rule malignancy out with a 4. Mine was a birad 5 and I was told there and then that my follow up appointment with the surgeon was just to confirm what type of cancer I had and get a treatment plan in place, and thankfully even then they were wrong. There is really no way of knowing until you get the biopsy results but with a birad 4 you've got great odds in your favour.  xx
Posts.Title: very very afraid...inverted nipple and mass :( cancersein Janet456

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2012 10:42AM Janet456 wrote: I feel for you, you sound like me back in the summer, the only difference is mine was screaming "cancer" from the outset and the experts wouldn't believe that everything was coming back benign. I hated them at the time for not just signing me off and letting me go to live my life. My outlook 7 months after the event is that I have never been so grateful to them.  My advice is to go with the flow, trust them, and take heart in the fact that you have a good BS.  I really do think you will have a good result but even if the news is not what you want it is going to be no where near as bad as you fear at this time courtesy of Dr Google. xx
Posts.Title: very very afraid...inverted nipple and mass :( cancersein Janet456

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2012 08:08AM Janet456 wrote: I am no expert but I would think that would be very unlikely. The birads 3 is a watch and wait scenario and the birads 4, although does require a biopsy still has an 80% chance of benign findings. At this stage the odds are in your favour.
Posts.Title: very very afraid...inverted nipple and mass :( cancersein Janet456

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2012 08:28AM Janet456 wrote: Sorry, that didn't work at all it just came out as a big mess of words. If you have a birads 3 it means that they have seen something but it is most probably benign, and watching and waiting should be done with a 6 monthly follow up just to see if it has changed or not.  The chances of it being malignant are less than 2%. Birads 4 does warrant a biopsy - but in approx 85% of biopsy's the results will be benign. Birads 5 means it is highly suspicious of malignancy with a less than 5% chance of it coming back benign. Hopefully somebody will be along to explain the other bits to you.

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2013 01:19PM - edited Feb 11, 2013 01:20PM by Janet456 Beesie - the Canadian system sounds much like here in the UK. Over here, when it all goes through quickly, it's time to worry - because that means they've got their foot on the gas. I actually waited 12 days for my biopsy results due to public holidays etc and there was no way they were going to be given out over the phone.   I cannot fault either my treatment or their methods and I know I couldn't have actually coped with "waiting for the phone to ring" either.  It was bad enough sitting in the waiting room at the alloted time of my appointment but at least I had a semblance of a normal life in those 12 days. xx

Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2012 12:55PM Janet456 wrote: Love the explanation of "flying blind".  Such a good way of explaining it. Mine is a BIRADS 5 and I had US Core guided biopsy which came back benign.   This then got me to the stage where the imaging and the biopsy results do not add up - meaning I had to have a further biopsy - which is still showing benign. I am having my lump removed this coming Friday and after 2 seperate biopsy's they are now 97/98% confident that they will be removing a tubular adenoma.   My surgeon wanted to be as sure as he can be what they are dealing with before they go in. Hoping you get good results. xx

Posts.Title: is 1mm enough margin? zha-an Janet456

Posts.Content: Janet456 wrote: Shall update tomorrow when the final scores on the doors will be in! It started off as a routine first off mammo, that went to crap fairly early on. To cut it short at this point, call back, diagnostic mamo, u/s, biopsy then to be told I would have "the works" thrown at me - oh lucky me :) Then I astounded them all a week later when the results were in with a birads 5 coming back B9.  Unbelievably to them so they do it all again and it's still B9 - and still they can't belive it so the whole lump has to come out and that is were we are now. I will get the final difinitive diagnosis tomorrow but the very fact that all along they way the medical profession are gobsmacked is making me very, very worried about what I will hear tomorrow.  I would love to be one of their odd "radiological/pathological discordance" stats and prove that you can be a birads 5 but still be OK, but my gut is still twisting in fear and I am dreading that long walk down "that corridor" to end up sitting in "that waiting room" once again.  I shall let you know tomorrow whether pathology trumps imagaing or it's the other way round. x  Surgery 7/12/2012 Lumpectomy: Left Dx 7/25/2012, DCIS, <1cm, Grade 2 Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: 2 months of waiting and the final answer tomorrow! Janet456 megnayak

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2012 02:32AM Janet456 wrote: Thank you ladies. Back from the hospital and the 5cm by 3cm lump was a tubular adenoma as the 2 sets of biopsies stated BUT when they examined the whole thing after the lumpectomy 9mm on the outer edge was DCIS. I now feel very fortunate that they were so adamant that it had to come out.  No need for another op, they got clear margins and it is less than a centimetre so have just been given an appointment for radiation. Janet xxx
Posts.Title: 2 months of waiting and the final answer tomorrow! Janet456 megnayak

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2013 11:49AM Janet456 wrote: Right so they have upgraded you from a Biards 4 to a Birads 5 on imaging and ultrasound? Nothing is conclusive until the pathology of the biopsy results are in although with a Birads 5 there is much more likely hood of a diagnosis. HOWEVER - do not panic just because they used the word "invasive", this just means they are assuming at this stage that whatever is diagnosed has more than likely left the ducts i.e. it will not be DCIS which is contained within the ducts. Invasive means in open breast tissue - it does not mean it has spread beyond this point so please take a deep breath, take somebody with you to appointments and things will get much better and easier once you have a plan in place. xx You are at the very worst part now. Things will get better xxx
Posts.Title: 45 yr old found a 3cmx1.5cm AnnieeC Janet456

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2012 05:56PM Janet456 wrote: Thanks for asking domesticwoman. Yesterday I had the wire put in under local anesthetic, I was dreading it but it was a doddle actually.  I was first on the surgeons list this morning so I was in la-la land by 9.00am.  Am home again now, it hurts a fair bit now but nothing too unmanageable and I have got Co-codomol to take. I am back on 25 July for the final results of the entire lump.  Two separate biopsy's taken a week apart, have said it is a tubular adenoma so am keeping everything crossed that this lumpectomy just confirms that and doesn't throw up any surprises. xx

With a Biards 4 rating I don't think you should have been told that at all...... at the moment your lump is seen as "suspicious" which is far removed from "highly suspicious". Keep us posted and I hope all turns out well xxxx

Posts.Content: May 23, 2013 10:30AM Janet456 wrote: Tertib - yes mine didn't correlate either.  There are various methods to diagnose i.e. examination, mammogram, ultrasound and biopsy and they have to concord with one another. If it doesn't (as it didn't in my case with a birads 5) they re did all the biopsies and as it was still benign they then sent me for a lumpectomy - so they could look at the whole mass not just a part of it. x

Posts.Title: MRI dustyGreen dustyGreen

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2014 03:33AM Janet456 wrote: Sorry you find yourself here but welcome. I am in the UK and over here if you have a rating of Birads 5 it doesn't matter what any other diagnostic tools come up with i.e. additional ultrasounds and biopsies they will keep going until they get an answer that is concordant. A similar thing happened to me, Birads 5 followed by biopsy which came out benign….. so yes Radiologists can be that wrong. The only way to know for sure is to have the biopsies.  Keep pushing until you get the answers. I understand the roller coaster you are on now as mine took 4 months from start to finish.  Not easy but hang in there. Good luck xx
Posts.Title: So very confused initial BIRADS 5 multiple lesions, mulitfocal BrigidSteed Janet456

When it doesn't match up the only thing to do is have the whole lump/mass examined so go with the second radiologist. Worrying times but my final pathology stayed the same as the biopsy results - I am sure yours will too, but it is the only way to know for sure. Best wishes to you xxx

Posts.Title: "thickening breast lump" Dr. Today help answer some questions!! the5owens MILCHICK

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2013 05:22PM Janet456 wrote: Hi Yell1724 Yes it happened to me.  BC is diagnosed through different imaging and biopsy tests and they should all work together.  What happened in my case was the imaging was screaming BC but the biopsy came back benign, in which case they have to get to the bottom of the discrepancy and get the results to "concord". I had another lot of biopsy's taken a week later when I was still bruised and battered but it was not a problem, they numb you up well so don't worry about that.  My second lot came back benign too so they then decided to take the whole lump out to make 100% sure that they weren't missing anything else. x
Posts.Title: Has anyone ever has this? Yell1724 OldOakTree

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2013 01:51AM - edited Jan 29, 2013 02:05AM by Janet456 I think your BS is being very thorough and wants to put an actual name to whatever it is - "B9 findings" can cover alot of things so she wants to know exactly what it is to be satisifed - thats good. My lump was in actual fact 100% benign, it was a tubular adenoma but on imaging tests looked way to scary to ignore.  My DCIS was picked up as an incidental finding in as much as when they cut the lump out 9mm very close to the outside of the benign lump was DCIS. I was told to think of my big lump as my Fairy Godmother so I do :) xx Keep us posted as to how you get along and best wishes to you for more B9 results xx
Posts.Title: Has anyone ever has this? Yell1724 OldOakTree

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2013 10:23AM Janet456 wrote: Hats off to your BS - exactly the kind of person you want on your side at times like this. You are treading exactly the same path I went down last year so I now exactly how you feel. Whatever the outcome, and with all this digging around you can be assured that whatever is there they will find it, but also be assured that with every benign result nothing will be as bad as you might imagine right now. Well done you for turning up and getting closer to the end result.  You will be fine xxxx

Posts.Title: Mass removal after benign BIRADS 5 biopsy overkill? Hummbird15 Hummbird15

Posts.Content: Janet456 wrote: This is my first post so apologies if I ramble on.  It's all a bit of a shock really.  Have never noticied anything amiss until 7 May when I thought I felt "something different" in the shower.  It was enough to worry me but by the next day with alot of proding and poking I had convinced myself it was nothing.  It was definately not a lump, more of a curve if that makes sense.  Having decided that there was no need for the doctors etc matters were then taken out of my hands as I received an invitatation for a first mammogram (I will be 50 in September). I went along, call back was almost immediate and 2 days later I was at the specialist breast unit in the hospital - (no portacabin in a supermarket car park this time round!). Another mammogram, ultrasound and a biopsy followed along with being told "it" was 5cm by 3cm and they would be treating it aggressively in view of my age and I assume the size, also I could expect to be very busy for the rest of the year going back and forth to hospital.   At that point my world fell apart.  I was made an appt with a breast surgeon last Weds where I was to be told my treatment programme and what type it is.  I went along last Wednesday to be told by a Consultant that the results are showing benign (rather surprisingly to everybody on the team), but that could be due to the fact that the biopsy missed the target so I had a further 3 biopsy's taken.  Only one was taken the first time round. The first biopsy was taken under ultrasound and I am trying to think that it is a big target to miss but my head is still all over the place, and I guess it will be until next Wednesday now. I am hoping that they might have said something like - "oh we just need another biopsy as it was inconclusive and not enough tissue sample was taken".  I would have been none the wiser but I just feel now like they have got my hopes up only to bring them crashing down again next week.  Thanks for letting me ramble on, I just felt the need to get it off my chest to people who will understand. Janet x  Surgery 7/12/2012 Lumpectomy: Left Dx 7/25/2012, DCIS, <1cm, Grade 2 Log in to post a reply

Keep us posted on how you get on xxx

Posts.Title: Biopsy scheduled for Tues...but EyesOpen38 EyesOpen38

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2012 06:16PM Janet456 wrote: Well it was appointment day today for the results of the second lot of biopsies.   This was my third appointment.  First appt was to be told that it was BC and I could expect all four methods of treatment to be given.  Second appt was with surgeon who could not understand first biopsy results so wanted them redone, and today.........unbeliveably I was told that the second lot of biopsies had also come back as benign and although they do not know what my lump is yet they are fairly confident that it is now benign. Lumpectomy is now scheduled within the next 6 weeks and they are saying that there is still a slim chance that it could be BC because they cannot rule it out until lump has been analysed by histology. For now I just feel relieved and I will move myself to the "not diagnosed, but worried" section of this forum. I have learned so much through reading the posts on this forum and I have found it a great source of comfort. Janet xxx

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2014 02:06PM - edited Mar 7, 2014 02:07PM by Janet456 I would say yes.  If mammograms and ultrasound lead a radiologist to believe a biopsy is warranted then I would definitely have one. Ask what your birad score is after the mammogram.  If it's a birads 4 there is more than an 80% chance of a benign result, but a birad 4 does warrant a biopsy to be certain. You may very well not need one, if it is a cyst the ultrasound will pick up that it is fluid filled and not solid. Good luck xx

Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2013 03:48PM Janet456 wrote: I'm in the UK - and here it is the norm for things to move very quickly if you get a call back.  I was called back within days, had diagnostic mamo, ultrasound - where they confirmed it wasn't a cyst, then had the biopsy 5 minutes later. I hope you get a benign result - 85% of biopsy's are benign so the odds are in your favour xx
Posts.Title: Bad Case of the What Ifs! Hoppie Hoppie

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2014 07:34AM Janet456 wrote: Very interesting.  Only two people in my family got BC - myself and my aunt.  We both took Clomid. It was the early 90's - they took 13 eggs for IVF treatment which resulted in an ruptured ectopic.  I was nervous enough not to want to do it again so that was that and I am content with my lovely niece and nephew.   Years later I vowed that I would never take HRT - but I developed BC before I got to that point so it's not an option now anyway. Interesting thread.
